message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest polymyalgia rheumatica, which is often associated with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Serum creatinine kinase is not typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica. Therefore, option B is the most likely answer. Option A is incorrect because anemia is commonly seen in polymyalgia rheumatica, hence the low hemoglobin in this patient. Option C is incorrect because serum creatinine kinase is not typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica. Option D is incorrect because while C-reactive protein (CRP) levels can be elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica, ESR is a more commonly used indicator of disease activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), which is often associated with elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Serum creatinine kinase is not typically elevated in PMR. Therefore, the correct answer is elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and normal serum creatinine kinase. Serum C-reactive protein can also be elevated in PMR, but it is not the most specific marker for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest polymyalgia rheumatica or giant cell arteritis. A normal serum creatinine kinase will rule out polymyositis or dermatomyositis, and a normal C-reactive protein will rule out inflammatory bowel disease or cancer. However, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate is a common finding in patients with polymyalgia rheumatica.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). The anemia indicates inflammation and further tests should show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), which is a common finding in PMR. Serum creatinine kinase is not typically elevated in PMR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), which is commonly associated with elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Normal serum creatinine kinase (CK) rules out inflammatory myopathies. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), which is elevated ESR and normal CK.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and normal serum creatinine kinase. Option (B) best fits this description. Elevated C-reactive protein may also be present, but is not as specific as elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest polymyalgia rheumatica, which often presents with elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and normal serum creatinine kinase (CK). CK is not elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica, which distinguishes it from other conditions that cause muscle pain and weakness such as polymyositis and dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms point towards polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), which is characterized by pain and stiffness in the neck, shoulders, and hips, as well as fatigue and fevers. PMR is often seen in association with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, but there is no evidence of that in this case. An initial work-up reveals low hemoglobin, which is a common finding in PMR, and the expected result in the work-up would be an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and normal serum creatinine kinase (CK). ESR is a standard test for PMR and is often elevated, while CK is usually normal. The other options are not associated with PMR.

Serum creatinine kinase is not typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica. Elevated serum C-reactive protein is also a common finding in polymyalgia rheumatica, but it is not the expected result in the work-up mentioned in the question.
